title: Delirium versus Dementia — Diagnostic Evaluation
icd10: F05 (Delirium due to known physiological condition)
scope: ** Systematic evaluation to differentiate delirium from dementia and identify reversible causes of acute confusion. Covers ED evaluation of altered mental status, inpatient delirium prevention and management, outpatient evaluation of cognitive complaints with possible delirium superimposed on dementia. Excludes detailed management of specific dementia subtypes (see Alzheimer's, Vascular Dementia, and other dementia-specific templates). Focuses on the diagnostic differentiation and acute management.

Core Labs (ALL Patients with Acute Confu.rationale: Electrolyte derangement (Na, Ca, glucose); renal failure (uremia); hepatic failure (encephalopathy); dehydration
Core Labs (ALL Patients with Acute Confu.target: Normal electrolytes; normal creatinine; normal LFTs; glucose 70-180

Core Labs (ALL Patients with Acute Confu.rationale: UTI is the most common precipitant of delirium in elderly
Core Labs (ALL Patients with Acute Confu.target: Negative; positive → treat only if symptomatic (asymptomatic bacteriuria common in elderly and should not be treated to "fix" delirium)

Core Labs (ALL Patients with Acute Confu.rationale: Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia as immediate reversible cause
Hepatic encephalopathy (if liver disease history or stigmata)
Intoxication, overdose, or drug-induced delirium; anticholinergic burden
Sepsis as cause of delirium; especially if febrile or hemodynamically unstable
Pneumonia (common delirium precipitant in elderly); CHF

Extended Labs (Guided by Clinical Suspic.rationale: B12 deficiency causing reversible cognitive impairment; common in elderly
Hypomagnesemia causing confusion; common with diuretics, alcohol, and malnutrition
Adrenal crisis causing confusion and hemodynamic instability
Extended Labs (Guided by Clinical Suspic.target: >10 mcg/dL (AM); ACTH stim test if suspicious

Extended Labs (Guided by Clinical Suspic.rationale: Neurosyphilis (treatable cause of dementia); screen in all new dementia evaluations
HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder; screen in appropriate risk groups
Wernicke encephalopathy (confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia) — give thiamine empirically BEFORE glucose
Extended Labs (Guided by Clinical Suspic.target: Normal; low confirms Wernicke (but do NOT wait for result — treat empirically)

Extended Labs (Guided by Clinical Suspic.rationale: Medications are the most common modifiable cause of delirium; calculate anticholinergic cognitive burden (ACB) score
Extended Labs (Guided by Clinical Suspic.target: ACB score <3; identify high-risk drugs (diphenhydramine, oxybutynin, TCA, benzodiazepines)

Rare/Specialized.item: CSF analysis (cells, protein, glucose, cultures, HSV PCR)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: If meningitis/encephalitis suspected (fever, nuchal rigidity, rapid decline, seizures); autoimmune encephalitis
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal cell count; protein <45; glucose >40; negative cultures and PCR

Rare/Specialized.item: Autoimmune encephalitis panel (NMDA-R, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA-B)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Subacute confusion with psychiatric features, seizures, or movement disorder in young/middle-aged; rapidly progressive dementia
Rapidly progressive dementia over weeks-months; CJD evaluation
Occupational or environmental exposure history; chronic encephalopathy
Subacute confusion with cancer history or unexplained weight loss; limbic encephalitis
Acute intermittent porphyria causing confusion, abdominal pain, neuropathy

Essential Studies.timing: Immediate in ED for acute confusion; rule out acute structural cause
Essential Studies.target: No acute hemorrhage; no mass effect; no acute stroke; chronic atrophy (expected in elderly/dementia)

Essential Studies.timing: Administer at time of evaluation; validated delirium screening tool
Essential Studies.target: Positive = delirium; negative with low suspicion = consider dementia evaluation

Essential Studies.timing: Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) first; then CAM-ICU if RASS >=  -3
Essential Studies.target: Positive = delirium; RASS -4 or -5 = too sedated to assess (delirium cannot be assessed in coma)

Extended Studies.timing: If dementia workup indicated; subacute presentation; focal neurologic findings; age <65; atypical features
Extended Studies.target: Atrophy pattern (temporal = AD; frontotemporal = FTD); white matter disease; NPH (ventriculomegaly); structural lesion; stroke

Extended Studies.timing: If non-convulsive status epilepticus (NCSE) suspected; differentiating delirium vs psychiatric; refractory encephalopathy
Extended Studies.target: Delirium: diffuse theta/delta slowing; NCSE: epileptiform discharges; psychiatric: normal alpha background; CJD: periodic sharp wave complexes
Extended Studies.contraindications: None; requires cooperation (may need sedation for application)

Extended Studies.timing: Fever with confusion; meningismus; immunocompromised; rapidly progressive dementia; autoimmune encephalitis suspected
Extended Studies.target: Cell count, protein, glucose, gram stain, cultures, HSV PCR, VDRL; AD biomarkers (A-beta 42, p-tau, t-tau) if dementia evaluation
Extended Studies.contraindications: Coagulopathy (INR >1.5, platelets <50K); mass lesion with shift on CT

Rare/Specialized (Dementia Evaluation —.contraindications: Acute delirium (invalid during delirium); severe language barrier

Delirium Management — Non-Pharmacologic.indication: All delirium patients; cornerstone of delirium management

doseOptions.orderSentence: Reorientation and environmental modification Continuous Environmental

dosing.instructions: Provide clock, calendar, and familiar objects; ensure glasses and hearing aids are in place; maintain day-night lighting cycle; minimize room changes; use orientation cues ("It is [day/date], you are in [hospital]")
dosing.orderSentence: Reorientation and environmental modification Continuous Environmental

Delirium Management — Non-Pharmacologic.indication: All hospitalized patients at delirium risk

dosing.instructions: Cluster care activities to avoid nocturnal interruptions; minimize nighttime vitals/blood draws; maintain dark, quiet environment at night; bright light during day; avoid sedating medications at inappropriate times

Delirium Management — Non-Pharmacologic.indication: All hospitalized patients with delirium or delirium risk; single most effective prevention strategy

dosing.instructions: Out of bed to chair for meals; ambulate in hallway 2-3x/day with assistance; PT/OT involvement; avoid unnecessary restraints and tethers (Foley, telemetry, lines)

Delirium Management — Non-Pharmacologic.contraindications: Hemodynamic instability; acute fracture; airway compromise

Delirium Management — Non-Pharmacologic.indication: ALL delirium patients; delirium is a medical emergency indicating an underlying condition

dosing.instructions: Systematically identify and treat: infection (antibiotics), metabolic (correct Na, glucose, Ca, Mg), medication toxicity (discontinue offending agents), urinary retention (catheterize), fecal impaction (disimpact), pain (treat), dehydration (IV fluids), hypoxia (supplemental O2)

Delirium Management — Non-Pharmacologic.monitoring: Serial CAM; vital signs; labs trending; mental status

Delirium Management — Non-Pharmacologic.indication: All delirious patients; medications are the most common modifiable cause

doseOptions.orderSentence: Medication review and deprescribing Immediate Medical

dosing.instructions: Review all medications; calculate ACB (Anticholinergic Cognitive Burden) score; discontinue or reduce: benzodiazepines, anticholinergics (diphenhydramine, oxybutynin, TCA), opioids (minimize to lowest effective), sedative-hypnotics, steroids
dosing.orderSentence: Medication review and deprescribing Immediate Medical

Delirium Management — Non-Pharmacologic.contraindications: Balance against untreated conditions (pain, seizure, psychiatric)
Delirium Management — Non-Pharmacologic.monitoring: ACB score <3; delirium severity; withdrawal symptoms if tapering

Delirium Management — Non-Pharmacologic.indication: All patients with delirium + suspected alcohol use, malnutrition, or unknown history

dosing.instructions: Thiamine 500 mg IV TID for 3 days (Wernicke dosing); then 250 mg IV daily for 3-5 days; then 100 mg PO daily; give BEFORE glucose administration

Delirium Management — Pharmacologic (Sec.indication: Hyperactive delirium with agitation threatening safety (pulling lines, falling, violence); NOT for hypoactive delirium; NOT for sedation

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5 mg PO/IM (elderly); 1-2 mg in younger adults; q4-6h PRN; max 5 mg/day in elderly; lowest dose for shortest duration; IV only in ICU with telemetry

Delirium Management — Pharmacologic (Sec.contraindications: Parkinson disease; Lewy body dementia; QTc >500 ms; torsades risk; NMS history
Delirium Management — Pharmacologic (Sec.monitoring: QTc (obtain ECG before and during treatment); EPS/akathisia; sedation; NMS; vital signs

Delirium Management — Pharmacologic (Sec.indication: Agitation in delirium; preferred in Parkinson disease or Lewy body dementia over haloperidol (lower EPS risk)

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5-25 mg PO qHS or BID; max 100 mg/day; lowest effective dose; short course only

Delirium Management — Pharmacologic (Sec.monitoring: QTc; sedation; orthostatic BP; metabolic (glucose); EPS (low risk but possible)

Delirium Management — Pharmacologic (Sec.indication: Delirium prevention and sleep-wake cycle restoration; adjunct to non-pharmacologic measures

dosing.instructions: 3-5 mg at bedtime; may aid sleep-wake cycle restoration; evidence mixed but favorable safety profile

Delirium Management — Pharmacologic (Sec.indication: ICU delirium with agitation requiring sedation; preferred over benzodiazepines for delirium in ventilated patients

dosing.instructions: Start 0.2 mcg/kg/hr; titrate to target RASS; max 1.5 mcg/kg/hr; alpha-2 agonist; maintains arousability; may reduce delirium duration vs benzodiazepines

Delirium Management — Pharmacologic (Sec.contraindications: Severe bradycardia; advanced heart block; severe hypotension

Delirium Management — Pharmacologic (Sec.indication: Benzodiazepines WORSEN delirium except in alcohol/benzo withdrawal and seizures

dosing.instructions: Benzodiazepines are a major risk factor for delirium; avoid lorazepam, diazepam, midazolam for agitation in delirious patients; EXCEPTION: alcohol withdrawal (use benzodiazepine protocol) and seizures

Dementia Evaluation — Outpatient Treatme.indication: Mild-moderate Alzheimer dementia; consider after delirium resolves and dementia is confirmed

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg qHS; increase to 10 mg qHS after 4-6 weeks if tolerated; max 23 mg/day (moderate-severe AD)

Dementia Evaluation — Outpatient Treatme.contraindications: Sick sinus syndrome; AV block; active peptic ulcer; severe asthma/COPD
Dementia Evaluation — Outpatient Treatme.monitoring: GI effects (nausea, diarrhea, anorexia); bradycardia; syncope; nightmares; muscle cramps

Dementia Evaluation — Outpatient Treatme.indication: Moderate-severe Alzheimer dementia; may add to cholinesterase inhibitor

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily; increase by 5 mg weekly; target 10 mg BID; XR formulation: start 7 mg daily, increase weekly to 28 mg daily

Dementia Evaluation — Outpatient Treatme.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); seizure history (lowers threshold modestly)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for atypical delirium (young patient, no identifiable cause, focal signs, rapidly progressive), suspected autoimmune encephalitis, or NCSE evaluation
Geriatrics or hospital medicine for delirium prevention program implementation (HELP program — Hospital Elder Life Program) and complex geriatric care
Neurology/neuropsychology for outpatient dementia evaluation after delirium resolves: formal cognitive testing, dementia subtype characterization, and treatment planning
Psychiatry for behavioral management if severe agitation not responding to low-dose antipsychotics, or concurrent major psychiatric disorder complicating delirium management
Social work and case management for discharge planning, caregiver support, safety assessment, and community resources for patients with newly identified dementia
Palliative care if advanced dementia with delirium; goals of care discussion; comfort-focused management

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Delirium is a medical emergency indicating an underlying medical problem — it is not "normal aging" or "just confusion" and requires thorough medical evaluation

Family members are the most valuable resource for detecting delirium: inform the medical team if your loved one is "not themselves," more confused than usual, seeing things, or unusually agitated or withdrawn
Bring glasses, hearing aids, and familiar objects from home to the hospital — sensory deprivation and unfamiliar environments worsen delirium
Stay with the patient during hospitalization if possible — familiar faces and voices provide reorientation and reduce agitation more effectively than medications
Do not use physical restraints unless absolutely necessary for immediate safety — restraints increase delirium severity, duration, and risk of injury
After discharge, a new dementia evaluation may be recommended — delirium can unmask underlying cognitive decline that was not previously recognized
Report any worsening confusion, fever, falls, or inability to take medications after discharge — delirium can recur, and underlying causes may not fully resolve at discharge

Delirium Prevention (HELP Program Compon.item: Implement Hospital Elder Life Program (HELP) protocols: orienting communication, early mobilization, sleep protocol, hydration assistance, vision/hearing optimization, and cognitive stimulation
Avoid prescribing high-risk medications in elderly patients: benzodiazepines, anticholinergics, opioids (minimize), sedative-hypnotics (no zolpidem, no diphenhydramine for sleep)
Minimize urinary catheter use (remove within 24h if possible); each day with a catheter increases delirium and infection risk
Target light sedation (RASS 0 to -1) in ICU; daily sedation interruption; avoid benzodiazepine-based sedation protocols (prefer dexmedetomidine or propofol)
Ensure adequate pain management — undertreated pain precipitates delirium; use scheduled acetaminophen (not PRN); minimize opioids; use multimodal analgesia

differential.features: Acute onset; fluctuating attention; identifiable precipitant (infection, medication, metabolic); reversible
differential.tests: CAM positive; labs identifying cause; EEG: diffuse slowing; resolves with treatment of cause

differential.features: Insidious onset over years; progressive memory loss; preserved attention initially; no fluctuation
differential.tests: MoCA/MMSE declining; MRI (temporal atrophy); amyloid PET; CSF AD biomarkers; neuropsych testing

differential.features: Stepwise cognitive decline; executive dysfunction prominent; history of strokes/TIA; vascular risk factors
differential.tests: MRI showing strategic infarcts or extensive white matter disease; history of cerebrovascular events

differential.features: Visual hallucinations (early); fluctuating cognition (can mimic delirium); parkinsonism; REM sleep behavior disorder; severe neuroleptic sensitivity
differential.tests: Clinical criteria (McKeith); DaTscan (reduced uptake); AVOID haloperidol — use quetiapine if needed; fluctuations with consistent hallucinations

differential.features: Behavioral/personality changes (disinhibition, apathy); language changes; younger onset (45-65); preserved memory initially
Prolonged confusion without clear seizure activity; may have subtle motor signs (eye twitching, automatisms); prolonged post-ictal confusion
differential.tests: EEG showing continuous or frequent epileptiform discharges; trial of IV benzodiazepine

differential.features: Depression: psychomotor retardation, flat affect, coherent when engaged; psychosis: organized delusions, auditory hallucinations, clear sensorium; catatonia: immobility, posturing, waxy flexibility
differential.tests: Psychiatric evaluation; EEG (normal alpha rhythm in psychiatric); CAM negative; bush-Francis catatonia rating scale; lorazepam challenge for catatonia

differential.features: Confusion + ophthalmoplegia + ataxia (classic triad in <33%); alcohol use or malnutrition; RESPOND to thiamine
differential.tests: Low thiamine level (but treat empirically); MRI (mammillary body and periaqueductal enhancement); clinical response to IV thiamine

differential.features: Gait apraxia (magnetic gait) + urinary incontinence + dementia; triad develops over months
differential.tests: MRI (ventriculomegaly disproportionate to sulcal atrophy); Evans index >0.3; high-volume LP tap test (gait improves)

differential.features: Temporal relationship to medication changes; common offenders: anticholinergics, benzodiazepines, opioids, steroids, anticonvulsants
differential.tests: Medication reconciliation; ACB score; improvement with deprescribing

evidence.recommendation: CAM has sensitivity 94-100% and specificity 90-95% for delirium diagnosis
evidence.source: [Inouye SK et al. Ann Intern Med 1990](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2240918/)

evidence.recommendation: Hospital Elder Life Program (HELP) reduces delirium incidence by 33-40%
Multicomponent non-pharmacologic interventions are first-line for delirium prevention and management
evidence.source: [Hshieh TT et al. JAMA Intern Med 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25643002/)

evidence.recommendation: Antipsychotics do not reduce delirium duration or severity; use only for safety (agitation threatening patient/staff)
evidence.source: [Nikooie R et al. JAMA Intern Med 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31476770/)

evidence.recommendation: Benzodiazepines are a major risk factor for delirium and should be avoided except for alcohol withdrawal
Dexmedetomidine reduces delirium incidence in ICU compared to benzodiazepine sedation
Delirium superimposed on dementia occurs in up to 65% of hospitalized dementia patients
evidence.source: [Fick DM et al. J Am Geriatr Soc 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12366629/)

evidence.recommendation: Thiamine 500 mg IV TID for suspected Wernicke encephalopathy
evidence.source: [Galvin R et al. Eur J Neurol 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20642790/)

evidence.recommendation: MoCA is preferred over MMSE for cognitive screening; more sensitive for MCI and vascular cognitive impairment
evidence.source: [Nasreddine ZS et al. J Am Geriatr Soc 2005](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15817019/)

monitoring.frequency: Q8-12h in hospital; each nursing shift; every ED reassessment
monitoring.action: Intensify non-pharmacologic interventions; identify and treat precipitant; consider pharmacologic management for safety

monitoring.frequency: Q4h in ICU; with each sedation assessment
monitoring.action: Reduce sedation; identify delirium cause; switch from benzos to dexmedetomidine; early mobilization
Identify infection, hemodynamic instability, hypoxia as delirium precipitant

monitoring.frequency: Daily; at admission; at each care transition
monitoring.action: Deprescribe high-ACB medications; substitute safer alternatives
IV fluids for dehydration; nasogastric feeding if needed; ensure meals/snacks provided

monitoring.frequency: After delirium resolves (wait 1-3 months); baseline for dementia evaluation
monitoring.action: Formal neuropsychological testing; dementia workup if persistent cognitive impairment after delirium resolves

monitoring.frequency: At admission and discharge; at each OPD visit
monitoring.action: Rehab referral if not returning to baseline; home safety assessment; caregiver support

disposition.criteria: Reversible cause identified and treated (e.g., UTI, medication-related, dehydration); delirium resolving; safe home environment; caregiver capable of monitoring; PCP/neurology follow-up within 1 week
Mild delirium with treatable cause; awaiting lab/imaging results; IV medications or hydration needed for <24 hours; no acute safety concern

Delirium with unclear etiology requiring workup; delirium with no safe discharge disposition; unable to take medications or maintain hydration orally; new or worsening neurologic deficit; severe agitation requiring monitoring and medication titration

Delirium with hemodynamic instability; requiring intubation (airway compromise from aspiration, severe agitation); suspected NCSE needing continuous EEG; severe metabolic derangement (DKA, hyponatremia); Wernicke encephalopathy with hemodynamic instability
Post-delirium cognitive assessment in 1-3 months (delirium can unmask dementia); new MoCA <26 warrants formal dementia evaluation; outpatient MRI, neuropsych testing, labs for dementia workup
1 week post-discharge: medication reconciliation, delirium resolution confirmation, caregiver check-in; ongoing: medication deprescribing, fall prevention, advance care planning
